title: Glory Oil posts lowest fuel prices; challenges others to do so
text:
17 July 2015 18:06 CET Glory Oil posts lowest fuel prices; challenges others to do so By Myjoyonline 
Following recent adjustment in prices of petroleum products, local oil marketing firm, Glory Oil, has slashed its prices. 
Glory Oil now has the lowest prices at the pump, something the Bulk Oil Distribution Companies and the National Petroleum Authority had predicted. 
The company sells a litre of petrol at 3.45 cedis whilst diesel sells at 3.06 cedis a litre. 
The Ghana Oil Company Limited, Goil, has rates slightly higher than Glory Oil’s. A litre of petrol at Goil goes for 3.46 cedis whilst diesel is selling at 3.07 cedis a litre. 
Total Ghana and Shell, two of the biggest foreign players have rates slightly higher than those displayed by the local oil marketing companies. 
At Total, Super is sold for 3.538 cedis a litre, diesel goes for 3.144 cedis a litre whilst at Shell, a litre of Super and Diesel is selling at 3.51 and 3.12 cedis respectively. 
The price difference is precisely what was anticipated when the NPA embarked on a journey to deregulate the petroleum sector. 
Pricing of petroleum products and petrol politics had remained an albatross on the neck of government. 
Previous governments as well as this one, had always played politics with the price of the commodity. 
For years, successive governments, especially in election years, had kept the prices of petroleum products artificially low, raking up debt for the state. 
This year, however, government decided to bite the bullet and take its hands off the pricing of the product. 
It has been argued that allowing market forces to determine the prices could be in the interest of the consumer as competition could force down prices. 
The current price differences appear to validate this argument. 
Chief Operating Officer of Glory Oil, Edzordzi Dzikunu, will not say much except to emphasise that his company was able to set the lowest price because “we were able to negotiate well with our BDC.” 
He said the local oil marketing firms deem it a national duty to contribute to the building of the nation by setting their price at the lowest level possible. 
Meanwhile, the Africa Centre for Energy Policy (ACEP) believes the prices could have down further. 
At a press conference Friday, ACEP’s Executive Director, Dr. Mohammed Amin Adam presented computations that explained that the price reductions could have gone further down 
Fuel prices have gone down at the pump between 10-15 percent following significant appreciation of the Ghana cedi against the dollar. 
With Ghana sticking with an enhanced price deregulation policy, OMCs are now free to set its individual prices within a formula provided by the Bulk Oil Distribution companies. 
Per the new prices, petrol is now being sold between ¢15.00 to ¢16.00 down from the 18.00 cedis it was sold at prior to the reduction. 
But ACEP argues it is not enough.
